title: How to Sharpen a Knife with a Coffee Mug

steps.headline: Find a coffee cup that has a rough, flat bottom.
steps.description: Examine the bottom of your coffee cups to identify one that has enough rough space around the bottom. Consider using an older or “least favorite” cup as you may end up making a few marks on the bottom of the cup as you sharpen the knife. Use only a coffee cup. A teacup is typically too delicate and does not contain the rough bottom required for sharpening.

steps.headline: Gather knives that need to be sharpened.
steps.description: You can sharpen as you go or on an “as needed” basis or you can get everything together that has been dulled and complete the task in one pass. This technique works for all knife sizes and types (except butter knives) so feel free to apply this method across the board.

steps.headline: Turn coffee cup upside down so the bottom faces upward.
steps.description: Find a smooth, flat surface for this project and make sure the surface is not slippery (or wet). If the coffee cup slips from your hand while you are sharpening the knife, you could slip and cut your hand.

steps.headline: Hold the bottom of the coffee cup with your free hand to keep it firmly in place.
steps.description: The only way you’ll be able to sharpen the knife is to ensure the coffee cup does not move or slip.

steps.headline: Place the knife blade against the rough bottom of the cup and slide it back and forth.

Find a coffee cup that has a rough, flat bottom. Examine the bottom of your coffee cups to identify one that has enough rough space around the bottom. Consider using an older or “least favorite” cup as you may end up making a few marks on the bottom of the cup as you sharpen the knife. Use only a coffee cup. A teacup is typically too delicate and does not contain the rough bottom required for sharpening. Gather knives that need to be sharpened. You can sharpen as you go or on an “as needed” basis or you can get everything together that has been dulled and complete the task in one pass. This technique works for all knife sizes and types (except butter knives) so feel free to apply this method across the board. Turn coffee cup upside down so the bottom faces upward. Find a smooth, flat surface for this project and make sure the surface is not slippery (or wet). If the coffee cup slips from your hand while you are sharpening the knife, you could slip and cut your hand. Hold the bottom of the coffee cup with your free hand to keep it firmly in place. The only way you’ll be able to sharpen the knife is to ensure the coffee cup does not move or slip. Place the knife blade against the rough bottom of the cup and slide it back and forth.
